Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2008 02:27PM debstitchestoo wrote: Hey Deb.  I feel for you.  This is a tough time.  It's especially tough for your family.  I know I'm handling it a whole lot better than my hubby.  It's been a year since my stage iv diagnosis and it does get easier  to accept.  The diagnosis, that is, not the prognosis.  You're a fighter and once you get over the shock, you'll be back on top of your game.  Hugs and lots of support! Debbie
Posts.Title: I never wanted to post here, but what do I do now?? AlaskaDeb heatherpalmerton

Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2008 01:13PM debstitchestoo wrote: Hi Deb I recently saw an ear, nose & throat doctor who recommended a new product called Simply Saline.  It's a mist to moisturize the membranes.  He also recommended using Polysporin at night instead of vaseline.  I've been doing this routie for a couple of weeks now and have had significant improvement (like 80% better) of the dryness & bleeeding. Debbie
Posts.Title: problems w/ dry nose and mouth on chemo AlaskaDeb lv2cmp

Posts.Content: May 21, 2008 02:52PM debstitchestoo wrote: Hi ladies I haven't taken Avastin yet, just Taxol/Abraxane.  I used to get horrific nose bleeds but my ear nose & throat doctor suggested using a nasal mist (I use Simply Sinus) a couple  of times a day and putting a small amount of Polysporin on a Qtip and coat the lower portion of the nostrils at night.  I've been doing this for a couple of months and my nosebleeds have been cut about 90%.  Give it a try. Debbie
Posts.Title: Surprise AVASTIN tx today! badboob67 ali_lpn

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2008 06:23PM debstitchestoo wrote: Hi Diane Hi Diane There's no right or wrong answer.  You need to start somewhere and if it works...that's great and if not, you try something else.  Xeloda was my choice too and fully supported by my oncologist.  It appeared to work but I couldn't tolerate it.  I switched to weekly Taxol and it's been a breeze compared to the Xeloda.  Who knew?  I was so afraid of the iv chemo but it's been far easier on me.  Yeah, I lost my hair but it's growing back even though I continue my treatments.  I wish you all the luck in the world and peace with your decisions.  We all have enough on our plates, we shouldn't have to second guess ourselves too. Debbie

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2008 08:10PM debstitchestoo wrote: Hi Cheryl I'm so sorry you're in so much pain.  The over the counter drugs can only do so much.  I found that Robaxecet really worked for me when I ended up with a compression fracture at my T12.  I did do 5 radiation treatments and the pain has completely disappeared.  I understand how weepy you're feeling.  I'm at the peak of my chemo fatigue in this cycle and the humidity in our area is making it near impossible for me to breath.  I too feel like I don't know how to go on.  You're not alone.  Can you not call your regular oncologist?  He/she may be able to help you with some better pain killers or even have your scan moved up.  Which centre do you go to?  PM me if you'd like to talk. Debbie

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2008 01:14PM debstitchestoo wrote: I had rads (5 treatments) for my neck nodes.  Worked like a charm.  Had a sore throat for a week and some pink skin on my neck but no swallowing problems or blistering.  Actually, I had a rare case of radiation recall a month later when my chemo started.  Debbie
Posts.Title: Anyone have rads to mets in neck nodes? zarowny9 zarowny9

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2008 04:02PM debstitchestoo wrote: I'm getting one on Friday.  I posted a few weeks ago looking for assistance but no one seems to have any experience with it.  What I do know is that it's put in as an out patient procedure.  Mine will be attached to a bag and will use a clamp to drain & empty.  Apparantly it's an easy process but I will have home care for 3 days to care for the surgical area and train me how to drain the fluid.  I look forward to your thoughts as well. Debbie
Posts.Title: Pigtail Catheter Jackson debstitchestoo

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2008 05:53AM debstitchestoo wrote: Just a little update.  I had my pigtail catheter inserted on Friday.  I was well sedated & frozen so  didn't feel much.  When the freezing wore off, however, there was quite a bit of pain.  The tube is inserted into the plueral cavity fairly high up under my right breast & a little to my side and tunnels about 3- 4 inches under the skin and exits closer to thhe middle of my chest.  There is about 5 inches of tubing exposed with a self sealing connector on the end.They removed 1200 ml of fluid after the procedure.  After about an hour I went home & slept the rest of the day.  The next day I continued having quite a bit of pain and having only extra strength Tylenol to combat it.  I'm going to have words with the surgeon the next time I see him.  A home care nurse came in the next day and drained another 800 ml of fluid.  Yesterday, she only was able to drain 90 ml so we may have got most of it out now. She's going to skip today's visit and will try to drain some more tomorrow.  I was happy that I don't continually wear the bag.  The drainage with the bag is much more comfortable than the vacume bottles.  The pain is subsiding and Tylenol does manage to dull most of it.  I'm off to chemo this morning....I should be really out of it this afternoon.  Jackie, I hope you made out ok last Thursday.  I'll PM you later. Debbie
Posts.Title: Pigtail Catheter Jackson debstitchestoo

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2008 06:53PM debstitchestoo wrote: My respirologist said the bag is about 4"x6".  The tube is quite fine.  My respirologist says you can strap it to your leg if you want.  He says he has patients who go swimming with it. I did post on the BC mets board, but anyone with experience didn't have the bag, just used a pressurized jar to drain into.  This bag business is the latest & greatest. Doesn't sound all that great to me but it sure beats repetative thorocentisis. Good luck to you tomorrow. Debbie
Posts.Title: Pigtail Catheter Jackson debstitchestoo

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2008 06:25AM debstitchestoo wrote: Hi Zarowny Again, as stated in many places on this board, having rads or any treatment is a personal decision between the patient & the onocologist.  In my case, the superclavical & other neck nodes were pressing on nerves and has cause paralyzation of my vocal chords and a slighltly drooping eyelid which is an indication of Horners Syndrome.  In order to mitigate these problems, radiation was the right call for me.  I understand that radiation oncologists are reluctant just to radiate without just cause. Because of the intensive radiation to the breast/chest area in 2000, this radiation treatment needed to be modified to not overlap with the previous area.  I have been told that some areas can be re-radiated but it depends on the amount and style of radiation previously given.  This is a question I always ask before I accept treatment.  I had radiation to my spine last spring & I asked whether or not the area could be re-radiated and my rad onc said yes, if need be.  You are right in checking all of the facts and getting opinions but you need to choose a treatment which will deliver the best QOL without jeapordizing future treatments.  That's the tough line we walk.  Hugs to you from another Canadian Debbie

Posts.Content: May 7, 2008 04:25PM debstitchestoo wrote: Hi Robin  I did 3 cycles of Taxol (3 weeks on/1 off) and was then switched to Abraxane on the same schedule.  I've done 2 cycles of Abraxane.  Besides the fact that the Abraxane is easier (no pre-meds and faster) I don't notice a whole lot of difference in the side effects.  I haven't had the metallic taste or the neuropathy yet.  I do have fatigue but I'm still working full time and pushing myself to go on.  My 1st scans are next week to see how well the treatment has done.  I'm assuming the side effects are cumulative and that I could feel worse in the future but I'm encouraged by the length of time people have been on this drug.  My oncologist has never suggested a chemo break but it sounds like something you might need.  Talk to your oncologist.  As Roxanne said you shouldn't have to feel crappy. Debbie
Posts.Title: How long on Abraxane? BonnieVA lv2cmp

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2007 07:24PM debstitchestoo wrote: Hi there I'm on Xeloda too....same frequency.  I haven't vomited but I've sure felt like I was going too.  If the new medication doesn't help your mom, make sure you get in touch with the doctor again.  It may be that the dosage is too strong, as mine was and that it needs to be reduced.  I feel for her.  Tell her she's not alone. Debbie

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2008 09:03PM debstitchestoo wrote: Welcome back.  I've missed your posts. Debbie
Posts.Title: Where is Tender ? riverinerabbit Gitane

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2007 06:06PM debstitchestoo wrote: Thanks for posting this news Shen.  I too failed this year on femara, aromisin and xeloda.  I start weekly infusions of taxol alone next week.  I was very disappointed that I was blowing through the drugs so fast but your news has given me hope that maybe they will find a drug to reduce my liver, lung and bone mets.  My lung mets have caused the middle lobe of my right lung to collapse.  I also have swollen lymph nodes in my neck which are pinching the nerves that control my vocal chords, causing one of them to be paralyzed open so I hardly have any voice or wind to speak.  I'm exhausted from the effort to breath, the side effects of the xeloda and the recent radiation to my lymph nodes.  People like you give me hope that I can feel better.  Thanks!!!!
Posts.Title: Scan results with a good news shend debstitchestoo

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2008 06:50AM debstitchestoo wrote: Hi Deb There's no magical way to learn to cope.  It's really a one day at a time lifestyle.  For people who like to have their life well planned out, this can be a difficult adjustment.  I try to find enjoyment in every day.  I am still working but finding assignments that allow the flexibility for doctor's appointments and treatments are hard to come by.  So, I set myself one task everydayand if I accomplish it, I'm satisfied.  Everything else is gravy.  Now I choose to surround myself with family & friends who are supportive and uplifting and who want to talk about anything but cancer.  I limit visits with sad and negative people.  It's been a year from my mets diagnosis and it's been a rollercoaster ride as I strive to find my new normal.  But I am enjoying a good quality of life and am not sweating the small stuff anymore.  I've been reading your posts for a long time and your sense of humour and strength will return.  You will see that you really can live well with this diagnosis and you will push your fears to the background more & more as time passes.  There will still be fear and sadness, but it will become less present in your life as your will to live takes over.  Having no organ involvement right now gives you lots of time to feel well, so enjoy.  I had my superclavical lymph nodes radiated and they are no longer an issue. We're here for you Deb, just like everyone has been here for me. Hugs Debbie
Posts.Title: How do I cope with mets...anyone want to teach the 101 class?? AlaskaDeb slonedeb

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2008 01:50PM debstitchestoo wrote: Hi Lanef I had similar problems with the Xeloda.  I felt horrible and wondered if life was worth living.  I also thought my mets were worse than they were, based on how I felt.  i was given a 4 week break.  I started to recover but still didn't feel well.  The onc reduced the dosage when I restarted and then again as the awful symptoms came back.  We eventually gave up and switched to Taxoi chemo treatments.  What a walk in the park these treatments have been in comparison & I'm back to work full time.  My onc said that people think that the Xeloda treatments are easier because they are oral chemo but for some people they are really hard on the system. Everything you said about your mom, I experienced but now I feel quite well.  I'm hoping that the scans next month will show the cancer beating a retreat.  Maybe your mom should consider trying another treatment that might be more tolerable for her.  My onc said she didn't want me to suffer throughout my treatments and that she could make me feel better.  She was right!  Best of luck to you both....be positive and fight on! Debbie

Posts.Content: May 16, 2008 02:46PM debstitchestoo wrote: Hey Deb I recently changed from Taxol to Abraxane and I am totally enjoying the 1/2 hour infusion time and the no premeds.  I had such a high followed by such a crash from the steroids that I was an emotional mess 3-4 days after my treatment.  Now the symptoms of fatigue are more even and I can plan my days better.  At my hospital, they only do Abraxane treatments on Mondays, which certainly messes up my work schedule ( Friday absences were much easier explained to those not in the know), but I still am a little down on Tuesdays when I think I'm never going to feel better.  But by Wednesday, I'm my old chipper self.  If you can switch, I'd recommend it.  I did my staging scans this week & get the results next week.  Hoping for some tumour shrinkage. Debbie

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2007 03:40PM debstitchestoo wrote: Hi Nosurrender I'll be interested in the replies.  I started Xeloda last night; same dosage.  I fell very stange today, full of aches, nausea, light headedness, chills and completely out of it.  Did you experience that?  My onologist and the pharmacist said that if I experience severe anything to call them and they would stop the drug until they could reassess the correct dosage.  They both said not to worry, that the reduced dose would still work that they're just reducing the toxicity.  My onc told me that they have 14 chances to get it right (given the combination of the pill strengths). Debbie
Posts.Title: Xeloda problems nosurrender AliceJean

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2008 01:45PM debstitchestoo wrote: Hi Abby I was told that they won't radiate unless absolutely necessary. ie. pain that needs to be controlled.  If your mets are not causing any pain, they may not want to do anything right now.  As for your question, you can have pain flare after the radiation but then it subsides.  I have several bone met locations but they only radiated a compression fracture area in my spine where the mets were starting to compress in towards the nerves.  I had a lot of pain and the radiation made it worse temporarily but gradually the pain subsided and I have no pain now.  My radiation oncologist will only radiate to palliatate pain or to prevent nerve damage. Debbie
Posts.Title: bone mets no pain? abbyglp LuAnnH

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2008 12:26PM debstitchestoo wrote: Hi Dawn I hope there are some more responses to your question. When I was faced with my decision, I couldn't find any responses to my question or any other postings about the superclavical nodes.  I only had the left side radiated but the nodes in the right side also disappeared around the same time as the left ones did.  I had minimal side effects, sore throat, pink skin in the radiated area.  I was warned about difficult swallowing but I was able to eat everything.  My oncologist encouraged me to do the radiation because it works faster than the chemo does.  She also would have liked me to had the mediastinal nodes radiated but because of the intense radiation given to the breast area in 2001, the radiation oncologist said that the skin would just break down.  So I would encourage you to speak to the radiation oncologist before making your decision and find out if you radiate the neck, if it can be re-radiated if the lymph nodes return.  It seemed to be important to my oncologist to stop the spread in the neck nodes quickly.  There are some important nerves that travel down your neck that affect your voice, eyes, breathing, heart & digestive system.  I have Horners syndrom now and very little voice.  My ENT doctor says that even with the cancer stopped in the nodes,for now, the healthy nerve tissue does not regenerate and scar tissue remains in it's place.  The radiation worked for me in terms of stopping the progression but since I also have other mets, I continue on my chemo.  The chemo they are suggesting for you will be available if you progress elsewhere but the radiation will stop the one place you have mets now.  Hope this helps.  Sometimes I feel woefully lacking in helping with advice since this journey is relatively new for me too. Debbie
Posts.Title: Ladies Please Help Me,I feel Like it's crunch time.. zarowny9 Trevorrolph

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2008 12:43PM debstitchestoo wrote: Dawn, I understand you're scared & frustrated.  You need to take a deep breath and relax.  I totally get where you're coming from.  I was there too.  After a few failed treatments and the slowness of the lymph node shrinkage, I was worried too.  You need to have faith that this treatment or the next will get things under control.  You must not give up.  Give the radiation some time to work.....and it will work...and you'll feel a whole lot better.  You and your oncologist need to work on what's next so that you feel like you have a plan and not just bouncing around hoping for a miracle.  All of us metsters are just buying time until a cure is found.  We need to try to enjoy our lives day by day.  Having a plan gives us stability and allows us to tuck our fears away for a few hours.  You can do this.  There's a whole army of people ready to give you a hand. Debbie

Debbie
Posts.Title: How many with BC and autoimmune diseases like LUPUS, RA, ? badboob67 wintersocks

Posts.Content: May 10, 2008 05:28PM debstitchestoo wrote: Hi Oz I lost my hair when I started IV chemo (Taxol and now Abraxane) in January.  I was physically prepared with hats, scarves and a very expensive wig.  I totally hate the hats & scarves and never wear them.  They make me look like a cancer patient.  I primarily wear my wig every day or go commando around the house when I'm not expecting company.  My hair has started to grow back but it's just peach fuzz and not worth mentioning.  Since I will probably be this way for the rest of my life, I wonder how I'm going to come to terms with it.  Like Jordan, I hated losing my eyelashes & eyebrows.  While I'm pretty good with makeup, it's still a pain in the ass having to make my face up every day just to look normal.  I'm worried about wearing my wig this summer as I hear they're very hot.  There are days I just want to chuck my wig and I wonder if I will ever get over missing my hair.  I have a port because I have the world's worst veins and I love it.  I don't love the way it looks but I love not being stressed out when I go for chemo every week.  I'm with you....I hate this but we've got to do what we've got to do.  It sucks. I know. Debbie

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2008 04:42PM debstitchestoo wrote: I have had superclavical & other neck nodes diagnosed & treated.  Mine were swollen and tender like swollen glands.  They were small and then grew to where they were visable to the naked eye.  I never had any of the sensations that you are talking about, so maybe you are just experiencing nerve misfiring.  I did experience this sensation in my face and in my mouth and described it as those 'pop tart' candies we had as kids exploding in my mouth.  We never did find out what that was...it just went away. Debbie
Posts.Title: supraclavicular? katoMato badboob67

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2008 02:06PM debstitchestoo wrote: Sending some hugs your way until you get some from your family.  One thing that surprised me on my trip through this new adventure is how much control I have.  When you talk to your onc and if he suggests a treatment...and if you decide to proceed, do it when it's convenient to you.  Visit your family and then follow up when you return.  Bone mets are not fatal and if they're not causing pain....treatment can wait. Debbie
Posts.Title: bone mets no pain? abbyglp LuAnnH

Posts.Content: May 30, 2008 04:13AM debstitchestoo wrote: I was told by the clinic nutritionist that during chemo, that it is most important to eat the right things to help keep up our energy and to promote healthy cell rebuilding.  They suggest small frequent meals packed with protein and good carbs as well as our fruit & veggies.  The nutritionist says eating to prevent cancer and eating during treatment are not the same thing and that our focus on treatment should be to maintain our strength.  I know I have struggled with little or no appetite (followed by weight loss) to eating like a pig (followed by huge weight gain) depending on the treatment.  I'm just trying to make sure everything I put in my mouth counts for something and not just pleasure! Debbie
Posts.Title: weight gain on taxol & avastin? jordan debstitchestoo

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2007 08:43PM debstitchestoo wrote: I had rads to the t10-t12 area of my spine in April.  They just did 5 treatments and I've had no pain since. Debbie
Posts.Title: Radiation for how long? Catgo debstitchestoo

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2008 08:25PM debstitchestoo wrote: Hi Joni I'm sorry that the Arimidex failed you...it did me too.  I did 5 years on Tamox with the initial diagnosis  and then when diagnosed with mets she put me on Femara.  I did well with tumour shrinking for about 5 months & then it quit on me.  The Arimidex allowed progression right away.  My onc told me it was worth a try but it was only successful when the other hormonals had failed in about 25% of people.  I then went on to Xeloda which also allowed progression.  I'm now doing paclitaxel first as Taxol and now as Abraxane and I appear to be having some success.  I haven't had any scans recently but things seem to be going in the right direction.  I have lung, liver, bone & skin mets.  I'm still hoping for NED.  You shouldn't give up either.  I thought Iwas going to get a long time out of each drug that I tried but that doesn't seem to be the case.  I am hopeful that when I do find one that works that I can stay on it for a long time.  btw. this chemo is definately doable and much easier than the xeloda to tolerate.  I was really afraid of chemo but I'm doing fine and still working full time. Debbie
Posts.Title: MRI & Bones Scan show Progression jonimb faeriesong

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2008 02:12PM debstitchestoo wrote: KariLynn  I'm distraught over this news.  I had really hoped that you were going to catch a break.  Please enjoy your vacation and your family and don't give up hope.  You have an army of supporters willing you health and recovery.  Hugs, Debbie
Posts.Title: Very bad report KariLynn roseg

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2008 01:11PM debstitchestoo wrote: I'm sorry that your mom is feeling so poorly.  Surgery does take a lot out of a body and adding chemo to that would make it that much tougher for her to recover.  We all worry when we need to skip chemo, that things will get out of control.  Once she starts chemo again, the cancer will be beaten back, even with a long break.  Even more concerning to me is her sugar levels & BP.  Wednesday is not too far away and as long as she doesn't get worse, it should be ok to wait.  But if you're really worried, you should try to talk to the doctor on the phone or take your mom to the emergency department.  Sleep is good for her, as long as you can get her to eat a bit and make sure she stays hydrated.  Hugs for you both. Debbie
Posts.Title: Worrying about my mom ejohn Maya1

Posts.Content: May 30, 2008 06:41AM debstitchestoo wrote: Hi Tracy I was diagnosed with lung, liver & bone mets in Feb 2007.  I was treated with Femara for 4 months then Aromisin which failed immediately.  I started Xeloda in October and it appeared to be working but I couldn't tolerate the drug.  After many dose reductions, we decided that it wasn't doing the job that it needed to be doing and we switched to Taxol in January/08.  I developed severe heart palpitations so we switched to Abraxane in March/08.  The last scans 2 weeks ago show one of the 3 liver tumours is gone, one significantly smaller and one stable.  My lung nodules are significantly smaller & my bone mets stable.  My onc has a list of drugs we can move to next but I'm hoping that the Abraxane will work for a long time. Debbie
Posts.Title: thread on liver mets? Tracy1964 LuAnnH
